labels.analysis: The MCP Think Tank server is designed to enhance AI capabilities like Cursor and Claude by providing a structured environment for advanced reasoning, persistent memory, and tool orchestration. Its core functionality revolves around knowledge graph memory management, task management, and web research integration. The server enables multi-step reasoning (Sequential Thinking), maintains state across sessions (Persistent Context), and guides reflection without rigid constraints (Enhanced Reflection). The available tools support these features with capabilities like entity relation management, task planning, and web searches via Exa API.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "Memory Management" was chosen because the server's core functionality revolves around a knowledge graph system for persistent memory. Secondary labels "Data Analysis & Processing" (for structured reasoning) and "Web Search & Research" (for Exa API integration) were selected based on key features. No custom label is needed as the predefined categories sufficiently describe the server's capabilities.

tools.name: upsert_entities
tools.description: Create new entities or update existing ones in the knowledge graph using an upsert pattern

observations.description: Facts or observations about the entity

context.description: Optional context or situation relevant to this entity (e.g., project, meeting, or scenario)

update.description: If true, will fully replace an existing entity; if false, will only create if entity doesn't exist

entities.description: Array of entities to create or update

tools.name: create_relations
tools.description: Create multiple new relations between entities in the knowledge graph. Relations should be in active voice

tools.name: add_observations
tools.description: Add new observations to existing entities in the knowledge graph

entityName.description: Name of the entity to add observations to

contents.description: Observations to add to the entity

observations.description: Array of entity observations to add

tools.name: delete_entities
tools.description: Delete multiple entities and their associated relations from the knowledge graph

entityNames.description: Array of entity names to delete

tools.name: delete_observations
tools.description: Delete specific observations from entities in the knowledge graph

entityName.description: Name of the entity to remove observations from

observations.description: Observations to remove from the entity

deletions.description: Array of entity observations to delete

tools.name: delete_relations
tools.description: Delete multiple relations from the knowledge graph

tools.name: read_graph
tools.description: Read the entire knowledge graph

dummy.description: Placeholder parameter - this tool doesn't require parameters but returns the complete knowledge graph with entities and relationships

tools.name: search_nodes
tools.description: Search for nodes in the knowledge graph based on a query

query.description: Search query to find matching entities

tools.name: open_nodes
tools.description: Open specific nodes in the knowledge graph by their names

names.description: Array of entity names to retrieve

tools.name: update_relations
tools.description: Update multiple existing relations in the knowledge graph

tools.name: memory_query
tools.description: Query the memory store with advanced filters

keyword.description: Text to search for in observations

before.description: ISO date to filter observations before

after.description: ISO date to filter observations after

limit.description: Maximum number of results to return

tools.name: think
tools.description: Use the tool to think about something. It will not obtain new information or change the database, but just append the thought to the log. Use it when complex reasoning or some cache memory is needed. Consider including: problem definition, relevant context, analysis steps, self-reflection on your reasoning, and conclusions. Adapt this structure as needed for your specific thought process.

structuredReasoning.description: A structured thought process to work through complex problems. Use this as a dedicated space for reasoning step-by-step.

associateWithEntity.description: Optional entity name to associate this thought with

tags.description: Optional tags to help categorize and find this thought later

storeInMemory.description: Whether to store this thought in the knowledge graph memory

context.description: Optional context or situation relevant to this thought (e.g., project, meeting, or scenario)

plannedSteps.description: The total number of steps planned for this thinking process

currentStep.description: The current step number in the thinking process

selfReflect.description: Whether to perform a self-reflection pass after generating the answer

allowResearch.description: Whether to allow research via external tools during the reasoning process

reflectPrompt.description: Custom prompt for the self-reflection stage

researchQuery.description: Optional research query to execute during the reasoning process

formatOutput.description: Whether to apply markdown formatting to the output

formatType.description: The type of formatting to apply

tools.name: plan_tasks
tools.description: Create multiple tasks from a plan. Generates IDs and syncs with knowledge graph.

tools.name: list_tasks
tools.description: List tasks with optional filtering by status and priority.

tools.name: next_task
tools.description: Get the next highest priority todo task and mark it as in-progress.

tools.name: complete_task
tools.description: Mark a task as completed.

tools.name: update_tasks
tools.description: Update multiple tasks with new values.

tools.name: show_memory_path
tools.description: Return absolute path of the active knowledge-graph file.

tools.name: exa_search
tools.description: Search the web using Exa API

type.description: Search type: auto (default), keyword (exact matching), or neural (semantic search)

start_published_date.description: Filter results published after this date (ISO format)

end_published_date.description: Filter results published before this date (ISO format)

include_domains.description: Only include results from these domains

live_crawl.description: When to use live crawling: 'always' or 'fallback' (when cached not available)

tools.name: exa_answer
tools.description: Ask a question and get a sourced answer via Exa /answer API.

question.description: The question to ask and get an answer with sources

max_citations.description: Maximum number of citations to include in the answer (1-10)

server_info_crawled.name: Think Tank
server_info_crawled.author: @flight505/mcp-think-tank
server_info_crawled.overview:
MCP Think Tank is a powerful Model Context Protocol (MCP) server designed to enhance the capabilities of AI assistants like Cursor and Claude. It provides a structured environment for enhanced reasoning, persistent memory, and responsible tool usage. Key capabilities include advanced Sequential Thinking & Chained Reasoning, a robust Knowledge Graph Memory system with versioning, and intelligent Tool Orchestration with Call-Limit Safeguards. This platform empowers AI to tackle complex problems through structured analysis, maintain knowledge across sessions, and utilize external resources like web search, all while adhering to configurable usage limits.

üéØ Philosophy MCP Think Tank is built on three core principles:

Elegant Simplicity: Minimal, well-designed tools that complement AI capabilities rather than trying to replicate them. 
Enhanced Reflection: Gentle guidance fosters better reasoning and self-reflection without rigid constraints. 
Persistent Context: A simple, yet effective knowledge graph provides memory across conversations.

Key Features üí≠ Think Tool: Dedicated space for structured reasoning and self-reflection. üß© Knowledge Graph: Simple and effective persistent memory system. üìù Task Management Tools: Plan, track, and update tasks, integrated with the knowledge graph. üåê Web Research Tools (Exa): Search the web and get sourced answers using the Exa API. üîç Memory Tools: Easy-to-use tools for storing and retrieving information from the knowledge graph. ü§ù Client Support: Seamless integration with Cursor, Claude @Web, and other MCP clients. üõ°Ô∏è Tool Orchestration & Call Limits: Built-in safeguards for efficient and responsible tool usage with configurable limits. ‚ö° Content Caching: Performance optimization for file and URL operations with automatic duplicate detection. üîÑ Sequential Thinking: Enables multi-step reasoning processes with progress tracking. üîé Self-Reflection: Automated reflection passes to improve reasoning quality. üìä Structured Outputs: Automatic formatting of thought processes for better readability. üîó Research Integration: Seamless incorporation of web research findings into reasoning flows.

server_info_crawled.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

config = {
  "memoryPath": "/tmp/memory.jsonl"
}
# Encode config in base64
config_b64 = base64.b64encode(json.dumps(config).encode()).decode()
smithery_api_key = ""

# Create server URL
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@flight505/mcp-think-tank/mcp?config={config_b64}&api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())
